narrative:
As I sat at my desk, sorting through the stack of receipts from my recent trip to Tokyo for the annual Global Marketing Conference, I couldn't help but feel a sense of relief that I was able to attend the event. The conference had been a crucial opportunity for me to network with industry leaders and learn about the latest trends in digital marketing. As the marketing manager for our company, I knew that the insights I gained would be invaluable in helping us stay ahead of the competition. The trip had been a whirlwind of meetings, presentations, and networking events, but I had taken the time to document every expense, from the moment I stepped off the plane at Narita International Airport to the last-minute souvenir I picked up at the Tokyo Station.

According to our company's accounting policies, business travel expenses to foreign countries may be deductible, and I was eager to take advantage of this benefit. As I began to compile my expense report, I made sure to include every receipt, from the $1,200 airfare to the $500 hotel bill at the Shinjuku Westin. I also included the costs of meals and transportation, as well as the $50 taxi fare from the airport to my hotel. As I tallied up the total, I was pleased to see that my expenses came out to be a substantial amount, well within the limits allowed for business travel deductions.

After carefully reviewing my expense report, I submitted it to our accounting department for review and approval. I knew that by deducting these business expenses, our company could save a significant amount on its tax liability. As the marketing manager, it was my duty to ensure that I was taking advantage of every available tax benefit, and I was confident that this trip had been a worthwhile investment for our company. With my expense report approved, I could now focus on using the insights I gained at the conference to drive growth and innovation for our business.

question: Which travel expenses are deductible?
correct_answer: Ordinary and necessary business travel costs
reasoning_steps: To establish that ordinary and necessary business travel costs are deductible, consider the following reasoning steps:
Airfare is a common expense when traveling for business, which implies it is an ordinary part of business travel, making it potentially deductible.
Business travel expenses to foreign countries may be deductible, which suggests that if the trip is to a foreign country, expenses related to it can be considered for deduction.
The conference registration fee is a legitimate business expense, indicating that expenses directly related to business activities can be considered deductible.
